questions.text: You are walking in a park when you notice a person suddenly collapse and become unresponsive. You quickly assess the situation and suspect cardiac arrest. According to Basic Cardiac Life Support (BCLS) guidelines, what is the first appropriate action you should take?

options.label: A
options.text: Start chest compressions immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Check the scene for safety before approaching the victim

options.label: C
options.text: Call for help and get an AED before checking for responsiveness

options.label: D
options.text: Provide rescue breaths before checking for a pulse

questions.correct_answer: B. Check the scene for safety before approaching the victim
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:
  • ➤ Basic Life Support (BLS) and Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS)
  • ➤ Basic Life Support (BLS) and Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS)
  • ➤ Aspect Basic Life Support (BLS) Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS) Goal Maintain brain perfusion by supporting circulation and breathing. Maintain cardiovascular function with advanced interventions, including airway management, rhythm correction, and medication administration. Primary Users First responders (e.g., EMTs, nurses, rescuers with CPR certification). Healthcare professionals (e.g., physicians, paramedics, nurses with advanced training). Airway Management Basic methods: mouth-to-mask, bag-mask ventilation. Advanced airway techniques: endotracheal intubation, supraglottic airway devices. Breathing Support Rescue breaths or bag-mask ventilation. Continuous ventilation with advanced airway in place (1 breath every 6 seconds). Use of Defibrillation AED (Automated External Defibrillator) automatically detects rhythm and advises shock if needed. A defibrillator is used, but the healthcare provider makes the decision to shock based on rhythm analysis. Differential Diagnosis of Pulselessness Focuses on performing CPR and defibrillation without diagnosing underlying causes. Includes diagnosing and treating reversible causes of pulselessness like hypovolemia, tension pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, etc. Medication Use No medications were administered. Administers medications (e.g., epinephrine, amiodarone, atropine) Chest Compressions High-quality chest compressions (30:2 ratio for adults without advanced airway). Same chest compression techniques, with rhythm-guided interruptions for defibrillation or other interventions. Focus on Reversible Causes Not explicitly emphasized. Actively diagnoses and treats reversible causes (e.g., 5 H’s and T’s)

Aspect

Basic Life Support (BLS)

Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS)

Goal

Maintain brain perfusion by supporting circulation and breathing.

Maintain cardiovascular function with advanced interventions, including airway management, rhythm correction, and medication administration.

Primary Users

First responders (e.g., EMTs, nurses, rescuers with CPR certification).

Healthcare professionals (e.g., physicians, paramedics, nurses with advanced training).

Airway Management

Basic methods: mouth-to-mask, bag-mask ventilation.

Advanced airway techniques: endotracheal intubation, supraglottic airway devices.

Breathing Support

Rescue breaths or bag-mask ventilation.

Continuous ventilation with advanced airway in place (1 breath every 6 seconds).

Use of Defibrillation

AED (Automated External Defibrillator) automatically detects rhythm and advises shock if needed.

A defibrillator is used, but the healthcare provider makes the decision to shock based on rhythm analysis.

Differential Diagnosis of Pulselessness

Focuses on performing CPR and defibrillation without diagnosing underlying causes.

Includes diagnosing and treating reversible causes of pulselessness like hypovolemia, tension pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, etc.

Medication Use

No medications were administered.

Administers medications (e.g., epinephrine, amiodarone, atropine)

Chest Compressions

High-quality chest compressions (30:2 ratio for adults without advanced airway).

Same chest compression techniques, with rhythm-guided interruptions for defibrillation or other interventions.

Focus on Reversible Causes

Not explicitly emphasized.

Actively diagnoses and treats reversible causes (e.g., 5 H’s and T’s)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with sepsis is admitted to the ICU. During the hospital stay, the patient suddenly becomes unresponsive, pulseless, and apneic. An immediate ECG is performed, revealing chaotic, irregular waveforms without identifiable QRS complexes or P waves. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Asystole

options.label: B
options.text: Pulseless Electrical Activity

options.label: C
options.text: Ventricular Tachycardia

options.label: D
options.text: Ventricular Fibrillation

questions.explanation:
Shockable Conditions

Ventricular Fibrillation: is a life-threatening arrhythmia characterized by chaotic, irregular waveforms on the ECG with no identifiable QRS complexes or P waves. It results in ineffective quivering of the ventricles, leading to a complete loss of cardiac output and immediate loss of consciousness.

Ventricular Tachycardia (Option C): It is characterized by a rapid heart rate originating from the ventricles, typically defined as three or more consecutive ventricular beats at a rate exceeding 100 beats per minute. The ECG will show wide QRS complexes (≥0.12 seconds) that appear similar and occur regularly. In some cases, VT can still have a pulse.

Non-Shockable Conditions

Asystole (Option A): It is a state of no electrical activity in the heart, resulting in a flat-line ECG with no discernible waves (no P waves, QRS complexes, or T waves). It indicates a complete absence of cardiac activity.

Pulseless Electrical Activity (Option B): It is a condition where the ECG shows organized electrical activity (which may appear as normal sinus rhythm or other patterns), but the heart fails to contract effectively, resulting in no palpable pulse.


 

Aspect

Basic Life Support (BLS)

Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS)

Goal

Maintain brain perfusion by supporting circulation and breathing.

Maintain cardiovascular function with advanced interventions, including airway management, rhythm correction, and medication administration.

Primary Users

First responders (e.g., EMTs, nurses, rescuers with CPR certification).

Healthcare professionals (e.g., physicians, paramedics, nurses with advanced training).

Airway Management

Basic methods: mouth-to-mask, bag-mask ventilation.

Advanced airway techniques: endotracheal intubation, supraglottic airway devices.

Breathing Support

Rescue breaths or bag-mask ventilation.

Continuous ventilation with advanced airway in place (1 breath every 6 seconds).

Use of Defibrillation

AED (Automated External Defibrillator) automatically detects rhythm and advises shock if needed.

A defibrillator is used, but the healthcare provider makes the decision to shock based on rhythm analysis.

Differential Diagnosis of Pulselessness

Focuses on performing CPR and defibrillation without diagnosing underlying causes.

Includes diagnosing and treating reversible causes of pulselessness like hypovolemia, tension pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, etc.

Medication Use

No medications were administered.

Administers medications (e.g., epinephrine, amiodarone, atropine)

Chest Compressions

High-quality chest compressions (30:2 ratio for adults without advanced airway).

Same chest compression techniques, with rhythm-guided interruptions for defibrillation or other interventions.

Focus on Reversible Causes

Not explicitly emphasized.

Actively diagnoses and treats reversible causes (e.g., 5 H’s and T’s)

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought after collapsing at home. Upon arrival, he is found to be in cardiac arrest. The medical team begins resuscitation efforts and considers potential reversible causes. Which of the following is not considered one of the reversible causes of cardiac arrest?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypovolemia

options.label: B
options.text: Tension pneumothorax

options.label: C
options.text: Hypertrophied ventricle

options.label: D
options.text: Hypoxia

questions.explanation:
H's

T's

Hypovolemia

Tension pneumothorax

Hypoxia

Tamponade (cardiac)

Hydrogen ion (acidosis)

Toxins

Hypo-/Hyperkalemia

Thrombosis (coronary MI

Hypothermia

Thrombosis (pulmonary embolism)

questions.text: Assertion: Cardioversion is the preferred treatment for symptomatic supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Reason: Synchronized direct current (DC) shock is administered at the peak of the R wave to effectively restore normal sinus rhythm while minimizing the risk of ventricular fibrillation.

options.label: A
options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is a correct explanation of the assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not a correct explanation of the assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion is true, but the reason is false.

options.label: D
options.text: The assertion is false, but the reason is true.

questions.correct_answer: B. Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not a correct explanation of the assertion.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cardioversion

Defibrillation
Definition

A synchronized electrical shock to reset the abnormal heart rhythm.

 

An unsynchronized shock to correct life-threatening arrhythmias.

Mechanism

Synchronized with the R wave in the ECG (delivered at the peak of the R wave)

Delivered irrespective of the R wave (unsynchronized)

Physiological Effect

Stops abnormal contractions to allow the heart to reset, followed by the SA node resuming normal activity

Halts all electrical activity in the heart, hoping normal rhythm restarts

Indications

Performed in arrhythmias where the heart is still contracting but irregularly, such as: 

  • Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT)
  • Atrial Fibrillation (AF)
  • Atrial Flutter

Performed in life-threatening arrhythmias where the heart is not pumping blood effectively, such as:

  • Ventricular Fibrillation (VF)
  • Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia (VT)

Energy Level

Usually lower energy levels (e.g., 50-100 joules for AF)

Usually higher energy levels (e.g., 150-360 joules for VF)

Performed in

Elective procedure, typically not in emergencies.

Emergencies (like during a cardiac arrest).

Complications

Less risk of inducing dangerous arrhythmias due to synchronization.

Higher risk of inducing other arrhythmias (e.g., R-on-T phenomenon) if the shock is delivered improperly.

questions.text: In an ICU, during cardiac resuscitation, a flat line is observed on the ECG. The attending physician instructs the team to administer adrenaline and continue CPR. What is the primary objective of administering adrenaline in this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: To immediately restore normal sinus rhythm.

options.label: B
options.text: To convert asystole into ventricular fibrillation.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase myocardial oxygen demand.

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease preload on the heart.

questions.correct_answer: B. To convert asystole into ventricular fibrillation.
questions.explanation:
Resuscitation Steps for Asystole

Identify Non-Shockable Rhythm (Asystole)

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓
Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓
Establish intravenous or intraosseous lines for medication administration.

↓
Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Administer IV/IO after the first 2 minutes of CPR.

↓

Identify Rhythm

  • Non-Shockable Rhythm: Continue CPR and administer epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.

Goal: To increase the likelihood of developing a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is necessary for effective defibrillation.

  • Shockable Rhythm: Administer a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

↓
Advanced Airway Management

Airway: Secure the airway with endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation for adequate oxygenation.

↓
Continue CPR

Resume chest compressions for 2 minutes.

↓
Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Primary Focus: Address reversible causes, especially hypothermia.

↓
Repeat CPR and Epinephrine

Cycle: Continue repeating CPR and epinephrine administration every 3-5 minutes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male in the ICU experiences cardiac arrest, during which ventricular fibrillation is observed. Continuous cardiopulmonary resuscitation is in progress, and a defibrillator has been used multiple times, but the patient remains unresponsive. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Amiodarone

options.label: B
options.text: Administer Epinephrine

options.label: C
options.text: Perform Advanced Airway Management

options.label: D
options.text: Continue CPR with Compressions

questions.explanation:
Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Ventricular Fibrillation

Asystole

Ventricular Tachycardia

 

Pulseless Electrical Activity

 

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Immediate Recognition

Identify Shockable Rhythm: Recognize VF or pulseless VT.

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓

Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓

Defibrillation

After 2 minutes of CPR, deliver a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

If no change, administer a second shock immediately.

↓

Continue CPR

Resume CPR for 2 Minutes

Place an intravenous or intraosseous line for drug administration.

↓

Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Given IV/IO after 2 minutes of CPR to enhance coronary perfusion pressure.

↓

Advanced Airway Management

Secure Airway: Perform endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation.

↓

Further Defibrillation

Third Shock: If VF or pulseless VT persists, deliver a third non-synchronized shock.

Continue CPR for 2 More Minutes: Follow with additional CPR.

↓

Administer Antiarrhythmic Medication

Amiodarone 300 mg IV: Administer for shock-refractory VT to stabilize heart rhythm.

↓

Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Immediate Recognition

Identify Non-Shockable Rhythm: Recognize asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA).

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓
Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓
Establish intravenous or intraosseous line for medication administration.

↓
Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Administer IV/IO after the first 2 minutes of CPR.

↓

Identify Rhythm

  • Non-Shockable Rhythm: Continue CPR and administer epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.

Goal: To increase the likelihood of developing a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is necessary for effective defibrillation.

  • Shockable Rhythm: Administer a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

↓
Advanced Airway Management

Airway: Secure the airway with endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation for adequate oxygenation.

↓
Continue CPR

Resume chest compressions for 2 minutes.

↓
Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Primary Focus: Address reversible causes, especially hypothermia.

↓
Repeat CPR and Epinephrine

Cycle: Continue repeating CPR and epinephrine administration every 3-5 minutes.

questions.text: A patient is on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the management of their ventilation parameters?

options.label: A
options.text: A tidal volume of 10 mL/kg lean body weight is recommended for ARDS patients.

options.label: B
options.text: The respiratory rate should not be increased in cases of raised intracranial pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: FiO2 was initially set at 1.0 and then reduced to maintain adequate oxygenation.

options.label: D
options.text: PEEP typically ranges from 8 to 10 cm of H2O for optimal alveolar recruitment.

questions.correct_answer: C. FiO2 was initially set at 1.0 and then reduced to maintain adequate oxygenation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the hospital and placed on mechanical ventilation. His arterial blood gas analysis shows the following values: PaO2: 86 mmHg, PaCO2: 50 mmHg and pH: 7.32. Which of the following management strategies should be prioritized for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease the tidal volume to improve ventilation.

options.label: B
options.text: Increase the FiO2 immediately to avoid oxygen toxicity.

options.label: C
options.text: Increase PEEP to improve oxygenation and maintain lung recruitment.

options.label: D
options.text: Increase the respiratory rate to enhance CO2 removal and improve pH.

questions.correct_answer: D. Increase the respiratory rate to enhance CO2 removal and improve pH.
questions.explanation:
Patient A

Patient B

Patient C

Parameters

pH: 7.4 (Normal)

pO2: 60 (Deficient)

pCO2: 40 (Normal)

pH: 7.2 (Acidosis)

pO2: 100 (Normal)

pCO2: 60 (Increased)

pH: 7.44 (Alkalosis)

pO2: 100 (Normal)

pCO2: 30 (Decreased)

Diagnosis

Hypoxemia

Respiratory Acidosis

Respiratory Alkalosis

Management

  • ↑ FiO2 to improve oxygenation (Option B)
  • But prolonged high FiO2 can lead to oxygen toxicity
  • Therefore maintain target PaO2 with the lowest FiO2 required.
  • ↑ PEEP to keep alveoli open. (Option C)
  • Optimal PEEP enhances gas exchange and reduces the risk of atelectasis.
  • ↑ Respiratory rate to remove CO2, thus lowering PaCO2. (Option D)
  • ↑ Minute volume
  • ↑ Tidal volume (Vt) also enhances CO2 removal.
  • ↓ Respiratory rate to allow CO2 accumulation in alveoli, thereby increasing PaCO2
  • ↓ Tidal volume (Vt) can ↑ PaCO2 levels, but with caution to ensure adequate ventilation. (Option A)

questions.text: A post-surgery patient is placed on mechanical ventilation, and the medical team is deciding whether to continue using Assist-Control Ventilation (ACV) or switch to Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation (SIMV) to support the weaning process. Which of the following statements about ACV and SIMV is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: ACV provides both patient-triggered and time-triggered breaths for full support.

options.label: B
options.text: SIMV allows spontaneous breaths between mandatory breaths, aiding in weaning.

options.label: C
options.text: ACV reduces the work of breathing and helps manage respiratory acidosis/alkalosis.

options.label: D
options.text: SIMV cannot adjust automatically to maintain minute ventilation

questions.correct_answer: D. SIMV cannot adjust automatically to maintain minute ventilation
questions.explanation:
Mechanical Ventilation Mode

Assist-Control Ventilation (ACV)

Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation (SIMV)

Features 
  • The mechanical ventilator is set at:
    • Tidal volume (VT): 500 ml
    • Respiratory Rate: 12/minute
    • FiO2: 40%
  • The most commonly used mode of invasive mechanical ventilation in intensive care units.
  • Key feature is that it provides a supported breath for both patient-triggered or time-triggered breaths. 
  • Volume control ventilation mode.
  • Delivers a set number of mandatory breaths with a preset volume while allowing spontaneous breaths when airway pressure drops below end-expiratory pressure.

Advantages 
  • Increases patient comfort by allowing them to trigger breaths as needed.
  • Enables easy management of CO2 levels to correct respiratory acidosis/alkalosis.
  • Reduces the patient's work of breathing.
  • SIMV is used to help wean patients from the ventilator.
  • Adjusts automatically to maintain minute ventilation.
  • Allows normal alveolar ventilation, avoiding acute respiratory alkalosis by preserving the patient's ventilatory drive.

Disadvantages  
  • Volume-cycled ventilation can lead to barotrauma, especially in stiff lungs; monitoring plateau pressures is crucial.
  • Tachypnea or insufficient exhalation time can cause breath stacking and auto-PEEP, increasing intrathoracic pressure and leading to hypotension; disconnecting the ventilator briefly allows full exhalation.
  • Hyperventilation may occur, causing respiratory alkalosis; adequate sedation can prevent this.
  • There is a potential for asynchrony between patient and ventilator, where a machine-driven inspiration may overlap with the patient's spontaneous exhalation.
  • This can increase the work of breathing, potentially leading to hypoventilation or pneumothorax.
Image

Ventilation " data-author="" data-hash="8785" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="500" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/NGxNyAxn8CL2otx42vF41744303656.png" width="500" />

questions.text: A patient on mechanical ventilation is being monitored using ventilator waveforms. Based on the waveform interpretations, which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The upslope of the volume vs. time scalar represents the expiratory volume.

options.label: B
options.text: A negative value on the flow vs. time scalar represents expiratory flow.

options.label: C
options.text: PEEP is indicated by the peak inspiratory pressure on the pressure vs. time scalar.

options.label: D
options.text: The middle steep part of the pressure-volume curve indicates low lung compliance.

questions.correct_answer: B. A negative value on the flow vs. time scalar represents expiratory flow.
questions.explanation:
Volume vs. Time Scalar

Flow vs. Time Scalar

Pressure vs. Time Scalar
  • Graphically represents the amount of gas delivered into the lungs over time by the ventilator.
  • Upslope: Represents the inspiratory volume. (Option A)
  • Downslope: Represents the expiratory volume.
  • Use: Helps to identify air leaks, air trapping, and patient’s spontaneous breathing efforts and is useful for evaluating changes in tidal volume with adjustments in ventilator settings.
  • Represents gas flow between the patient and the ventilator.
  • Inspiratory Flow: Positive value on the graph.
  • Expiratory Flow: Negative value on the graph. (Option B)
  • The area under the curve: Indicates the volume moved during breathing phases.
  • Use: To identify the mode of ventilation. It provides information about the patient's exhalation.
  • Displays pressure in the airway as a function of time, which can be fixed or variable depending on the mode of ventilation.
  • Baseline Pressure: Indicates PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure). (Option C)
  • Peak Inspiratory Pressure (PIP): Maximum pressure at the end of the curve.
  • Plateau Pressure (Pplat): Represents airway pressure under static conditions (no airflow), obtained during an inspiratory hold.
  • Use: Provides valuable information about airway compliance over time.

Pressure-Volume Curve

Flow-Volume Curve

  • Shows pressure (cm water) along the x-axis and volume (mL) along the y-axis.
  • Inspiratory curve forms a sigmoidal shape:
    • Initial Flat Part: Represents air movement into collapsed airways with low compliance.
    • Middle Steep Part: Indicates lung recruitment. (Option D)
    • Flattening at End: Represents the end of inspiration.
  • Hysteresis: Failure of the lung tissue to act the same with inspiration and expiration.
  • Expiratory curve resembles a football shape.
    • Flatter Slope: Indicates decreased lung compliance.
    • Steeper Slope: Indicates increased lung compliance.
  • It shows volume (mL) on the x-axis and flow rate (L/min) on the y-axis.
  • Inspiratory Limb: Flow reaches zero at the end of inspiration.
  • Expiratory Limb: Curve completes when both volume and flow return to zero, indicating the end of expiration.
  • Obstructive patterns: Show a “scooped out” appearance on the expiratory limb, with concavity indicating lower flow at a given volume.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is on mechanical ventilation. His healthcare team is evaluating the best ventilation mode to optimize his care. Which of the following statements regarding Pressure Control Ventilation (PCV) and Pressure Support Ventilation (PSV) is correct, particularly if the patient’s respiratory effort is minimal?

options.label: A
options.text: PCV guarantees a specific tidal volume regardless of lung compliance.

options.label: B
options.text: In PSV, tidal volume is guaranteed and does not depend on the patient's effort.

options.label: C
options.text: PCV limits peak airway pressures, beneficial for patients at high risk of barotrauma.

options.label: D
options.text: PSV is used for heavily sedated patients with no spontaneous breathing efforts.

questions.correct_answer: C. PCV limits peak airway pressures, beneficial for patients at high risk of barotrauma.
questions.explanation:
Pressure Control Ventilation (PCV)

Pressure Support Ventilation (PSV)

Mechanism

  • Tidal volume in PCV varies depending on lung compliance. (Option A)
  • PSV is entirely patient-triggered and controlled.
  • Tidal volume is not guaranteed in PSV and depends on lung compliance and the patient’s ability to sustain an inspiratory effort. (Option B)

Advantages

  • PCV is useful for limiting peak airway and lung distending (plateau) pressures.
  • It is often used in conditions where high pressures could cause harm, such as ARDS or after thoracic surgery. (Option C)
  • Limit barotrauma if the patient's respiratory effort is minimal.
  • Inspiratory flow rate can vary with patient effort (improved comfort/synchrony)
  • Patient effort is preserved and controls tidal volume, inspiratory flow and respiratory rate, allowing for ventilator synchrony.
  • Commonly used in patients who are less sedated and able to participate in breathing, often during weaning from mechanical ventilation or when the ventilator is used mainly for airway support. (Option D)

Disadvantages

  • PCV does not assure a specific tidal volume, so tidal volume and minute ventilation need to be monitored.
  • Spontaneously breathing patients on PCV can generate negative pressure in the circuit, leading to increased inspiratory flow rates and tidal volumes, which raises transalveolar pressure and heightens the risk of volume or barotrauma.
  • Apnea and hypoventilation are possible
  • Must monitor respiratory rate, tidal volume and minute ventilation closely.
Images

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with congestive heart failure presents with acute shortness of breath, orthopnea, and bilateral pulmonary crackles. ABG reveals hypoxemia. Which of the following interventions will improve both oxygenation and reduce preload and afterload in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: High-flow nasal oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP)

options.label: C
options.text: Non-rebreather mask

options.label: D
options.text: Intubation

questions.explanation:
Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)

CPAP delivers constant positive pressure to the airways throughout the respiratory cycle (inspiration and expiration).

It helps maintain airway patency, improve oxygenation, reduce atelectasis, and enhance ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) matching.

Indication
  • Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA): Maintains airway patency in patients with conditions like obesity, hypotonia, and adenotonsillar hypertrophy.
  • Neonatal Respiratory Distress: Used in NICU for preterm infants with underdeveloped lungs and surfactant deficiency.
  • Infant Respiratory Conditions: Treats hypoxia, bronchiolitis, pneumonia, and tracheomalacia by reducing the work of breathing.
  • Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Improves oxygenation and cardiac output in heart failure patients, promoting better V/Q matching.
  • Pre-Intubation Support: Provides positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to enhance oxygenation before intubation.
  • Extubation Support: Helps extubated patients (e.g., those with OSA or heart failure) who still benefit from positive pressure.
  • Heart Failure: Reduces the need for intubation in acute cardiogenic pulmonary oedema by decreasing preload and afterload. (Option C)
  • Chronic Pulmonary Diseases (COPD and Asthma): BiPAP reduces the work of breathing, improves gas exchange, and prevents respiratory failure progression.
  • Acute Bronchitis and Pneumonia: Improves oxygenation and reduces breathing effort, especially in patients with chronic lung disease.

Contraindications
  • It is not recommended for patients with poor respiratory drive, severe anxiety, unstable cardiorespiratory status, facial trauma, copious secretions

Equipment and Techniques
  • CPAP machines consist of a motor, air filter, tubing, and mask interface (nasal, nasopharyngeal, or full-face mask). 
  • Special CPAP systems like bubble CPAP are used for neonates. 
  • Humidifiers and auto-titrating machines improve patient comfort and therapy effectiveness.

Complications
  • Common side effects include nasal congestion, dry mouth, bloating, and mask discomfort. 
  • Compliance is a major issue, and patient monitoring is crucial to adjust settings and address discomfort.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of COPD presents with increasing dyspnea, productive cough, and confusion. Arterial blood gas (ABG) shows pH 7.30, pCO₂ 58 mmHg, and pO₂ 55 mmHg. He is hemodynamically stable. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate endotracheal intubation

options.label: B
options.text: Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (NIV)

options.label: C
options.text: Intravenous antibiotics only

options.label: D
options.text: High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.explanation:
Noninvasive Positive-Pressure Ventilation (NIV)

NIV refers to positive-pressure ventilation delivered through a nasal or full-face mask, either at a continuous pressure (CPAP) or with varying inspiratory and expiratory pressures (BiPAP).

Modes:
Modern noninvasive ventilators can provide full support, including volume control ventilation.

Indications
  • Acute respiratory failure: This treatment is effective for conditions that respond quickly to treatment, reducing the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
  • COPD exacerbations: NIV benefits moderate hypercarbia (pH 7.25-7.35), reducing the need for intubation and hospital stay. Severe respiratory acidosis (pH < 7.2) may require mechanical ventilation with intubation. (Option B)
  • Cardiogenic pulmonary oedema: Acts as adjunctive therapy, improving gas exchange and respiratory mechanics alongside diuresis and vasodilators.
  • Chronic respiratory failure: This is useful in restrictive lung diseases (e.g., severe scoliosis, respiratory muscle weakness) and chronic hypercapnia in COPD, reducing hospital admissions when used nocturnally.

Advantages

  • Reduces work of breathing
  • Improves pulmonary compliance
  • Recruits collapsed (atelectatic) alveoli
  • Requires less sedation compared to invasive ventilation
  • Shortens hospital stay
  • Lowers intubation rates without the risks of endotracheal intubation

Contraindications
  • Inability to protect the airway (e.g., severe encephalopathy)
  • High aspiration risk (e.g., vomiting, upper GI bleeding)
  • Difficulty clearing respiratory secretions
  • Facial trauma/surgery
  • Upper airway obstruction
  • Significant hemodynamic instability
